section.description: The monster Grendel emerges from the moors and attacks Heorot
section.line: Þær grim ond gredie, godes yrre bær,
feorhsecan flota, se þæ fram fen cwom,
of morsele myndum; he mid mægne wearð
godes ægyldanne. Grendel gongan sceal,
deaðfæge deog; nales don wolde
æfter heorte hygge, þæm þe hine mid adum scean,
þær wearð Grendel gram, geong sunne grad,
gongan eard unfær. Godes witu brægd,
þære scean sceolde, scenden minne leofan.

section.description: Beowulf hears of Grendel's attacks and sails from Geatland to help King Hrothgar
section.line: Hwæt, we have heard of the glory of the Spear-Danes,
of their readiness to avenge the cruel attacks of Grendel,
And Beowulf, of the Geats, brave and strong,
decided to sail across the whale-road to help the Danish king,
taking his warriors with him to face the monster.

section.description: Beowulf and his men arrive at Heorot
section.line: Over the whale-road came the Geats' ship,
swift and sea-worthy, bringing Beowulf and his band
to the Danish shore, to King Hrothgar's hall,
where Grendel's ravages had brought sorrow and despair.
The hero stood bold before the Danish king,
ready to do battle with the monster from the moor.
Grendel gongan sceal,
deaðfæge deog; nales don wolde
æfter heorte hygge, þæm þe hine mid adum scean.
Beowulf lét him þæs lices wealdend,
wrace wræðes cyning. He mid þære winde fand
deoplic þurhfær, deaðes nyðe.

section.description: Grendel's defeat and retreat to his lair
section.line: Þær wæs sangeres cwyde, þær was sorg and weorðe,
blóð bleted geond þæt hús, þær wæs gryreleoð strong,
deoðlic dreamunge, deaðes hwilte sang.
Grendel fleah geond þæt mor, morðres gefylled,
æt his heorðe, heaþucræftig mon;
he habban sceolde hygelace leofan.

section.description: The Danes celebrate Beowulf's victory, but Grendel's mother seeks revenge
section.line: Þær wæs symbel in sele, sorhleas mægen,
dryhtne driþæne, dugude æt sete.
Drince we sceoldon, dræm wæs þær micel,
heard under heorðe, hwilum scylde þegn
wordum wrixlað. Þær wæs wlanc Beowulf,
wundrum micel, worðmyndum þah;
ac on morgenrice, mære cwom sece,
grim ond gyre, Grendeles modor.
